channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Business Briefing | Regulatory News: W.T.O. Backs U.S. Appeal on Chicken Tariffs in China
item.description: The World Trade Organization ruled in favor of the United States in a longstanding dispute over allegations that China unfairly imposed tariffs that restricted American poultry exports.
item.dc:creator: By ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Business Briefing | Regulatory News: Outbreak of Stomach Illness Is Traced to a Salad Mix
item.description: The Food and Drug Administration said an outbreak of stomach illnesses in Iowa and Nebraska was linked to salad mix served at Olive Garden and Red Lobster restaurants and supplied by a farm in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: By ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Drone War Rages on, Even as Administration Talks About Ending It
item.description: Mixed messages by officials reveal a deep-seated ambivalence inside the Obama administration about just how much light ought to shine on America’s shadow wars.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI and MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry at the American Embassy in London.

item.title: Group Rooted in the Desert Looks Out for Migrants
item.description: Volunteers patrol the Arizona desert — ready to offer water, food, clothing and medical care — aiming to prevent deaths in a harsh landscape.
item.dc:creator: By FERNANDA SANTOS
item.media:description: William Berk, 25, and Lydia Delphia, 21, hiked through the desert carrying water to drop for migrants.

item.title: Qaeda Messages Prompt U.S. Terror Warning
item.description: Intercepted electronic communications in which senior operatives of Al Qaeda discussed attacks in the Middle East and North Africa led the United States to issue a global travel alert to its citizens, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: The United States Embassy in Baghdad, among nearly two dozen that will be closed because of new security concerns.

item.title: Egypt Says It May Shut Entrances to Camps
item.description: As clashes between demonstrators and security forces continued in and near Cairo, the Egyptian government threatened to block entrances to a large protest camp.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Narciso Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women who support Egypt’s ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, demonstrated Friday in the Nasr City section of Cairo. Scores have died in recent clashes.

item.title: Berlusconi’s Followers Threaten Fragile Truce in Italy
item.description: Members of the former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s party talked of mass resignations to protest his prison sentence for tax fraud.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi told fellow party members Friday that the decision by Italy’s highest court the day before to uphold his prison sentence for tax fraud was “groundless.”

item.title: In Mali, a Race Between a Former Finance Minister and a Pro-French Favorite
item.description: Mali will hold a runoff on Aug. 11 between two presidential candidates, Ibrahim Boubacar Keita and Soumaila Cissé.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Ibrahim Boubacar Keita is a former Malian prime minister.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Deadly Clashes Raise Tensions in Kashmir
item.description: The Indian Army has killed a dozen people suspected of being rebels in five days of fighting near the highly militarized line, an army spokesman said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Tunisia: Military Hunts Militants Near Algerian Border
item.description: Aircraft bombed caves in the Mount Chaambi area, where the military has been trying to track down a band of 15 to 20 Islamist militants since December, an army spokesman said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Yemen: Fighting Erupts Between Groups of Soldiers
item.description: Hundreds of members of Yemen’s elite Republican Guard, now dissolved, gathered near the presidential palace, to demand that the Finance Ministry pay them a Ramadan bonus.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Alarms Warned Train’s Driver Before Accident
item.description: The alarms went off inside the train that crashed last week in northwestern Spain moments before it derailed, prompting the panicked driver to activate the brakes three times, an examination revealed.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Prime Minister Insists He’ll Stay in Power
item.description: Hopes for a compromise solution to a deadlock over election results faded Friday as Prime Minister Hun Sen insisted that he could form a new government even if the opposition boycotted Parliament.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Blast Caused by Methane Gas, Report Says
item.description: The basement blast killed 37 people and injured more than 120 others at the headquarters of Petróleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, on Jan. 31.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Iran’s President-Elect Provokes Furor Abroad With Remarks on Israel
item.description: Hassan Rouhani’s remarks were reported as being more harsh by the Iranian media, and Israel said Mr. Rouhani showed his “true face” with the comments.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Iran's new president, Hasan Rouhani, center, attended a celebration for the annual pro-Palestinian holiday in Iran known as Quds Day, named after the Arabic name for Jerusalem.

item.title: Pope Sends Message of Respect for Muslims
item.description: Francis personally signed a Vatican statement of friendship at the end of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: The Saturday Profile: In Mandela Legacy, a Place for Winnie?
item.description: During Nelson Mandela’s hospitalization, Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, his former wife, has made an ostentatious re-entry into the public arena.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: “If we sometimes sound bitter, it is because we are dealing with a very difficult situation,” said Winnie Madikizela-Mandela.

item.title: The Lede: Video Shows Iran’s President-Elect Was Misquoted on Israel
item.description: Video of comments made on Friday by Iran’s president-elect, Hassan Rouhani, showed that he was misquoted by Iranian news agencies and had not called for the destruction of Israel.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Chinese Journalist Detained in Beijing, One Day After Human Rights Talk With U.S.
item.description: The journalist, Chen Min, who had pressed for the release of a prominent human rights activist, was called to a meeting with security officials in Beijing at around noon on Friday.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Pressed on Syria, Hezbollah Leader Urges Focus on Israel
item.description: Hassan Nasrallah said his Shiite followers would not bend in the face of rising anti-Shiite sentiment among those who oppose his support for the Syrian government.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Mugabe’s Party Appears Headed for Parliamentary Victory in Zimbabwe
item.description: Early results from the vote, which observers gave a mixed report, showed ZANU-PF, President Robert G. Mugabe’s party, earning a big majority in Parliament. There was no word yet on the presidential race.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:credit: Pete Muller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zimbabwean men played a game in the Mabvuku township outside Harare, which is largely sympathetic to Robert G. Mugabe's main challenger, the Movement for Democratic Change.

item.title: Report Paints Dire Picture in Honduran Prison Fire
item.description: The Honduran authorities had known about the high risk of fire since at least 2004, the report said, citing “severe structural deficiencies” in the administration of the country’s prisons.
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY
item.media:description: Inmates’ relatives clashed with the police outside the prison in Comayagua, Honduras, last year after a fire killed 362 people.

item.title: Egypt General Has Country Wondering About Aims
item.description: Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi is riding a wave of muscular nationalism and pro-military sentiment, leaving questions of how quickly he intends to return the country to civilian rule.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle of Germany, left, shook hands with Gen. Abdul Fattah al-Sisi on Thursday in Cairo.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: August 2
item.description: Muslims breaking their fast at Jama Masjid, a mosque in Old Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Muslims gathered at Jama Masjid, a mosque in Old Delhi, to break their fast during the last Friday of the holy Islamic month of Ramadan.

item.title: U.S. Envoy and Putin Aide Discuss Snowden
item.description: There were signs that the United States and Russia might try to contain the fallout over Russia’s decision to grant temporary asylum to Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive intelligence analyst.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
